title: Merkel & Brussels SAVAGED for doing 'a TERRIBLE JOB' during the Greek economic crisis
text:
Merkel & Brussels SAVAGED for doing 'a TERRIBLE JOB' during the Greek economic crisis Merkel & Brussels SAVAGED for doing 'a TERRIBLE JOB' during the Greek economic crisis ANGELA Merkel and the European Union have been blasted as “terrible” for their handling of Greece’s economic crisis, the country’s former finance minister has claimed. PUBLISHED: 01:29,   02:37, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 GETTY Varoufakis blasts Merkel and the EU for their handling of Greece's economic crisis 
Yanis Varoufakis, who resigned from his prestigious economic position, slammed the union for failing to adequately settle the country’s crisis which he deemed "manageable". 
Varoufakis told CNN: “Isn’t it yet another piece of evidence that the European Union is particularly good at doing a terrible job, but handling what should be a very manageable crisis.” Related articles Yanis Varoufakis blasts EU and says Greece crisis is due to bloc 
In a separate scathing attack, the 55-year-old blasted Germany's politicians for focusing on their election campaigns and creating bailout plans that they knew Greece couldn't follow. 
Wolfgang Schauble, Germany’s finance minister who launched Greece's bailout programme was said to be "determined" to get Greece out of the EU, which is why he made such a difficult bailout. GETTY Wolfgang Schauble, Germanys finance minister was criticised for launching a bailout doomed to fail 
Merkel on the other hand has been accused of being too focused on her election campaign, leaving Greece at the brink of leaving the union. 
The former Greek finance minister said: “The people at the IMF [International Monetary Fund]… told us that the Greek debt is unsustainable and the austerity that is being [imposed] upon Greece is catastrophic for the program itself. 
“Merkel simply wants to extend and pretend until the German election is out of the way. The Greek government pretends it’s going to fulfil its target… but won’t do it. Yet again. It’s Europe.” 
On Monday, Greece and its international lenders agreed to a new set of reforms that would deal with Greek pensions, income tax and the labour market in exchange for a new tranche of loans. Protest in Greece turns violent Wed, November 16, 2016 Protests in Greece turn violent following a protest against the visit of the US president in Athens on November 15, 2016 Play slideshow 1 of 34 
Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the chair of the Eurozone Finance Ministers group said the new policy is a step away from "austerity, putting more emphasis on deep reforms". 
But the news comes after new research claimed 22.2 per cent of the Greek population are now “severely materially deprived”. 
Varoufakis added: “Schauble wants Grexit, Merkel doesn’t want Grexit. They haven’t worked it out… Until they make up their mind, this government is going to stay in power.” Related articles
